channel.title: NYT > U.S. News
channel.copyright: Copyright 2020 The New York Times Company

item.title: As the Virus Deepens Financial Trouble, Colleges Turn to Layoffs
item.description: The University of Akron this week became one of the first schools in the country to make profound cuts in the number of full-time professors on its staff. Others might have to follow.
item.dc:creator: Daniel McGraw, Shawn Hubler and Dan Levin
item.media:credit: Jeff Chiu/Associated Press
item.media:description: The chancellor of the University of California, Berkeley, cited uncertain fall enrollment, “particularly with our international student population,” as one of several financial pressures facing the university.

item.title: Mask Rules Expand Across U.S. as Clashes Over the Mandates Intensify
item.description: More retailers and states are instituting mask requirements, but tensions are mounting for people who see the rules as infringements.
item.dc:creator: Sarah Mervosh, Manny Fernandez and Campbell Robertson
item.media:credit: Dustin Chambers for The New York Times
item.media:description: Face masks on display in the window of a custom clothing print shop in Atlanta.

item.title: Seeing ‘Black Lives Matter’ Written in Chalk, One City Declares It a Crime
item.description: In a small Washington town where people of color say they have faced discrimination, activists ran into trouble for drawing “Black Lives Matter” in the streets. Then their white neighbors came to their defense.
item.dc:creator: Mike Baker
item.media:credit: Jovelle Tamayo for The New York Times
item.media:description: Gabriel Fabian, his girlfriend, Melissa Martinez, and sister Solimar Fabian were invited by their neighbors to draw chalk messages on their driveways in Selah, Wash., after earlier drawings on the street were removed by the city.

item.title: Washington State Beat Back Covid-19. Now It’s Rising Again.
item.description: Washington was the initial epicenter of the nation’s coronavirus outbreak, and an early lockdown helped contain it. Six months later, cases are spiking again, and the future looks uncertain.
item.dc:creator: Rachel Abrams
item.media:credit: Jovelle Tamayo for The New York Times
item.media:description: Yakima, Washington’s eighth-most populous county, now has the second-highest number of cases.

item.title: California’s ‘Bear Whisperer’ Is Out of a Job
item.description: Steve Searles kept the bears in check in Mammoth Lakes, Calif., but quit his post after the coronavirus epidemic led to cuts in the town’s budget.
item.dc:creator: Jason Nark and Akasha Rabut
item.media:credit: Akasha Rabut for The New York Times

item.title: Mistrust of a Coronavirus Vaccine Could Imperil Widespread Immunity
item.description: Billions are being poured into developing a shot, but the rapid timetable and President Trump’s cheerleading are creating a whole new group of vaccine-hesitant patients.
item.dc:creator: Jan Hoffman
item.media:credit: Rich Pedroncelli/Associated Press
item.media:description: An anti-vaccination rally on the steps of California’s State Capitol in Sacramento last month.

item.title: A Covid-19 Lesson: Some Seriously Ill Patients Can Be Treated at Home
item.description: To ease pressure on hospitals, Northwell Health brought medical workers, oxygen tanks and intravenous equipment into patients’ homes. Now Florida is taking cues.
item.dc:creator: Roni Caryn Rabin
item.media:credit: Johnny Milano for The New York Times
item.media:description: When Joan Murray of Westbury, N.Y., a registered nurse, came down with Covid-19, she insisted on fighting the illness at home. “The last place I wanted to be was the hospital,” she said.

item.title: Why Trump’s Attacks on John Roberts Aren’t Working With Some Conservatives
item.description: The Supreme Court has faded somewhat in importance as frustration with the president grows, according to Republicans in the Indiana county where the chief justice grew up.
item.dc:creator: Elaina Plott
item.media:credit: Taylor Glascock for The New York Times
item.media:description: Mitch Feikes outside his home in La Porte, Ind., where Chief Justice John G. Roberts Jr. attended high school.

item.title: Trump Promotes Caricature of What Conservatives Want
item.description: A series of events during his White House tenure has made clear that Mr. Trump views the voters he calls “my people” through the lens of what he imagines they like.
item.dc:creator: Maggie Haberman
item.media:credit: Doug Mills/The New York Times
item.media:description: Last month, following days of protests over racial justice, President Trump walked to a historic church near the White House to pose with a Bible.

item.title: Race Takes Center Stage as Rashida Tlaib Faces Primary Challenge
item.description: Some of Detroit’s most prominent Black leaders are backing a challenger to Ms. Tlaib, a Palestinian-American who has gained celebrity status since winning her seat in 2018.
item.dc:creator: Luke Broadwater and Kathleen Gray
item.media:credit: Sylvia Jarrus for The New York Times
item.media:description: Rep. Rashida Tlaib, Democrat of Michigan, is facing a bitter rematch in the Aug. 4 Democratic primary.

item.title: How PG&E Is Racing to Improve Safety as Fire Season Approaches
item.description: The utility, which recently emerged from bankruptcy, is upgrading power lines, trimming trees and making other changes to prevent another big fire.
item.dc:creator: Ivan Penn and Jim Wilson
item.media:credit: Jim Wilson/The New York Times
item.media:description: Crews are working across Pacific Gas & Electric’s vast California service area to reduce the fire risk from its power equipment.

item.title: Praise for John Lewis Pours in From Nation’s Political Elite
item.description: Mr. Lewis, who died on Friday at 80, was instrumental in the historic struggle for racial equality in the United States. “He risked his life and his blood” for his country, former President Barack Obama said.
item.dc:creator: Sheryl Gay Stolberg and Mike Ives
item.media:credit: Alex Wong/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Representative John Lewis receiving the Presidential Medal of Freedom from President Barack Obama in 2011.

item.title: John Lewis, Towering Figure of Civil Rights Era, Dies at 80
item.description: Images of his beating at Selma shocked the nation and led to swift passage of the 1965 Voting Rights Act. He was later called the conscience of the Congress.
item.dc:creator: Katharine Q. Seelye

item.title: Utility Company Gave Jobs to Allies of Top Illinois Democrat, Prosecutors Say
item.description: Illinois Speaker Michael J. Madigan has not been charged, but the governor, a fellow Democrat, said he must resign if the allegations are true.
item.dc:creator: Richard A. Oppel Jr.
item.media:credit: Rich Saal/The State Journal-Register, via Associated Press
item.media:description: Michael J. Madigan, the speaker of the Illinois House, in 2018.

item.title: Were the Actions of Federal Agents in Portland Legal?
item.description: The Department of Homeland Security can point to federal statutes protecting property to justify the arrests of protesters in Portland, Ore., but whether they stretched the law would be up to a judge.
item.dc:creator: Zolan Kanno-Youngs
item.media:credit: Doug Brown, via Associated Press
item.media:description: Agents across the Department of Homeland Security were deployed to protect a courthouse in Portland, Ore.

item.title: F.B.I. Agent in Russia Inquiry Saw Basis in Early 2017 to Doubt Dossier
item.description: Newly declassified documents added more fodder for the continuing political fight over an aspect of the Trump-Russia investigation.
item.dc:creator: Charlie Savage and Adam Goldman
item.category: Russian Interference in 2016 US Elections and Ties to Trump Associates
Wiretapping and Other Eavesdropping Devices and Methods
item.media:credit: T.J. Kirkpatrick for The New York Times
item.media:description: Peter Strzok, a former F.B.I. counterintelligence investigator, played a key role early in the bureau’s Russia investigation.

item.title: Biden’s School Plan Draws Clear Contrast With Trump’s
item.description: Joseph Biden said the president’s insistence on getting students and teachers back in the classroom, despite the virus, was “just plain dangerous.” Mr. Biden also warned that Russia and China were engaged in election meddling.
item.dc:creator: Katie Glueck
item.media:credit: Kriston Jae Bethel for The New York Times
item.media:description: In his school plan, former Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. emphasized that the decision to reopen should be local, with consideration for the safety of educators and students.

item.title: Coronavirus Briefing: What Happened Today
item.description: Americans still can’t stop fighting about masks.
item.dc:creator: Jonathan Wolfe and Lara Takenaga

item.title: Watchdog Faults Medicare Agency’s Use of Communications Contractors
item.description: An inspector general’s audit said the Centers for Medicare and Medicaid Service used communications contractors for work that should have been performed by public servants.
item.dc:creator: Margot Sanger-Katz and Noah Weiland
item.category: Centers for Medicare and Medicaid Services
item.media:credit: Doug Mills/The New York Times
item.media:description: Seema Verma of the Centers for Medicare and Medicaid Services accused the inspector general’s office of bad timing, saying that it had wasted resources on the inquiry during a public health crisis.

item.title: Breonna Taylor Shooting: Prosecutors Drop Felony Charges Against 87 Protesters
item.description: The Jefferson County attorney will expunge the charge from the records of an N.F.L. player, a reality TV star and 85 others who gathered this week on the Kentucky attorney general’s lawn.
item.dc:creator: Heather Murphy
item.media:credit: Mary Ann Gerth/Courier Journal, via Associated Press
item.media:description: Protesters gathered outside the home of Kentucky’s attorney general, Daniel Cameron, on Tuesday to demand charges in the killing of Breonna Taylor.

item.title: Newsom Order Would Keep Most California Schools Online
item.description: Districts in counties with rising caseloads will be required to teach remotely until conditions improve.
item.dc:creator: Jill Cowan
item.media:credit: Jim Wilson/The New York Times
item.media:description: Students at Buena Vista Middle School in San Francisco in February before the coronavirus outbreak forced school buildings to close.

item.title: Emily Howell Warner, Who Broke a Sky-High Glass Ceiling, Dies at 80
item.description: She was the first woman hired to command the cockpit for a major American airline on scheduled flights and the first woman to achieve the airline rank of captain.
item.dc:creator: Sam Roberts

item.title: 2 White Men Charged After Helping Pin Black Man to a Tree in Indiana, Officials Say
item.description: The charges came after Vauhxx Booker said on Facebook that he had been assaulted by a group of men who had threatened to “get a noose.”
item.dc:creator: Michael Levenson and Johnny Diaz
item.media:credit: Rich Janzaruk/The Herald-Times, via Associated Press
item.media:description: Two men have been charged in the Fourth of July weekend assault of Vauhxx Booker.

item.title: Are You Eligible for Food Stamps Now? Maybe, but It’s Complex
item.description: States run SNAP, and many students and older people don’t realize they’re eligible. Without more federal support, millions more may qualify.
item.dc:creator: Ron Lieber
item.media:credit: Robert Neubecker

item.title: Overlooked No More: Nancy Green, the ‘Real Aunt Jemima’
item.description: A nanny and cook, she played the part as the pancake flour company that employed her perpetuated a racial stereotype. She died 87 years ago in Chicago.
item.dc:creator: Sam Roberts

item.title: Conflict Over a Rental Car Leads to Elusive A.T.M. Skimming Suspect
item.description: He had more than 20 aliases and usually wore a mask. In the end, it was losing his temper with workers at the airport that led to his arrest, prosecutors said.
item.dc:creator: Heather Murphy
item.media:credit: Mark Lennihan/Associated Press
item.media:description: An investigator used a detection device to see if a credit card skimmer had been used at an A.T.M. in New York City.

item.title: No Bleach and Dirty Rags: How Some Janitors Are Asked to Keep You Virus-Free
item.description: Planes are wiped in under 10 minutes. Many custodians have to bring their own supplies. Yet as the U.S. reopens, companies are boasting of high safety standards to lure customers.
item.dc:creator: Jodi Kantor
item.category: Disney, Walt, World (Lake Buena Vista, Fla)
item.media:credit: Damon Casarez for The New York Times
item.media:description: “As soon as we disinfect it, someone else comes and touches it,” said Ellie Gonzalez, a part-time cleaner at Disneyland in California.

item.title: Pentagon Sidesteps Trump to Ban the Confederate Flag
item.description: The defense secretary lists the types of flags that are allowed to appear on bases worldwide. That flag does not fit.
item.dc:creator: Helene Cooper
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:credit: Pool photo by Greg Nash
item.media:description: Defense Secretary Mark T. Esper’s memo goes after the many American soldiers, Marines and airmen who display Confederate flags and other symbols in their barracks and in parking lots on military installations.

item.title: Government Says Contract for Covid-19 Database Was Competitively Bid
item.description: A $10.2 million contract to run the Trump administration’s new coronavirus database continues to draw scrutiny, but the government says it had six bidders.
item.dc:creator: Sheryl Gay Stolberg
item.category: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention

item.title: Inside Johnson & Johnson’s Nonstop Hunt for a Coronavirus Vaccine
item.description: In Boston and in the Netherlands, scientists are racing to build a vaccine against the virus strangling the world.
item.dc:creator: Carl Zimmer
item.media:credit: Tony Luong for The New York Times
item.media:description: Noe Mercado, a scientist at the Center for Virology and Vaccine Research in Boston, which is developing a coronavirus vaccine with Johnson & Johnson.

item.title: How One Student Chose a College During a Pandemic
item.description: Craig McFarland was accepted by all eight Ivy League schools. At first he committed to Yale, but the ongoing disruptions caused by the coronavirus caused him to change his plans.
item.dc:creator: Johnny Diaz
item.media:credit: Christa Assi
item.media:description: Craig McFarland of Jacksonville, Fla., was accepted at all eight Ivy League universities. He chose Harvard after committing to Yale.

item.title: Ginsburg Says Her Cancer Has Returned, but She’s ‘Fully Able’ to Remain on Court
item.description: The announcement touches off speculation about the possibility of a court opening as both parties seek to make the future of the Supreme Court an election issue.
item.dc:creator: Adam Liptak, Denise Grady and Carl Hulse
item.media:credit: Sarah Silbiger/Getty Images
item.media:description: Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg said she had begun chemotherapy in May.

item.title: Cave’s Clues Show It’s More Than Just Oldest Outhouse in the Americas
item.description: Preserved dung in Oregon’s Paisley Caves is helping to fill in some mysteries about some of the earliest people on our continent.
item.dc:creator: Asher Elbein
item.media:credit: Jeff Barnard/Associated Press
item.media:description: Archaeologists have found stone tools in the Paisley Caves, as well as material like coprolites that can be radiocarbon dated.

item.title: Mnuchin Calls for Congress to Pass More Stimulus This Month
item.description: The Treasury Secretary told lawmakers that the next phase of relief should be focused on industries that have been hardest hit by the coronavirus.
item.dc:creator: Alan Rappeport and Nicholas Fandos
item.category: Coronavirus Aid, Relief, and Economic Security Act (2020)
item.media:credit: Samuel Corum for The New York Times
item.media:description: Treasury Secretary Steve Mnuchin called on Congress to pass another round of stimulus aid as parts of the economy continue to struggle with the effects of the virus.

item.title: Democrats Eye Trump’s Game Plan to Reverse Late Rule Changes
item.description: President Trump pioneered the use of an obscure 1996 law to quickly reverse the regulations of his predecessor. Now Democrats hope to take a page from his game plan.
item.dc:creator: Coral Davenport
item.media:credit: Doug Mills/The New York Times
item.media:description: President Trump delivered a speech on Thursday celebrating his administration’s work to undo government regulations.

item.title: Portland Protests: Local Leaders Urging Feds to Leave
item.description: Federal authorities said they would bring order to Portland, Ore., after weeks of protests there. Local leaders believe the federal presence is making things worse.
item.dc:creator: Sergio Olmos, Mike Baker and Zolan Kanno-Youngs
item.media:credit: Dave Killen/The Oregonian, via Associated Press
item.media:description: Federal officers pulled a protester into a courthouse on July 10 as protesters gathered in downtown Portland, Ore.

item.title: Is California Doing Enough Coronavirus Testing?
item.description: California is among several states struggling to catch up to the recent surge in cases. Also: A call to prospective University of California students.
item.dc:creator: Marie Tae McDermott and Jill Cowan
item.media:credit: Max Whittaker for The New York Times
item.media:description: A testing site at the Robertson Community Center in Sacramento.

item.title: New Tools for Home Buyers as the Pandemic Upends Real Estate
item.description: As homeowners rethink their surroundings and rush to relocate, companies are offering creative ways to help ease a fraught process.
item.dc:creator: Paul Sullivan
item.media:credit: Rozette Rago for The New York Times
item.media:description: Working from home during the pandemic prompted Dan Feder to consider moving his family to another Los Angeles neighborhood to be closer to his son’s school.

item.title: 2020 Election Updates: Joe Biden Offers a Plan for Reopening Schools
item.description: As President Trump’s faltering poll numbers endanger Republican candidates down the ballot, Beto O’Rourke is focusing his resources on helping Joe Biden and the Democrats win Texas.
item.media:credit: Lucy Nicholson/Reuters
item.media:description: Social-distancing dividers were set up in a classroom in Montebello, Calif., this month.

item.title: C.T. Vivian, Martin Luther King’s Field General, Dies at 95
item.description: A disciplined advocate of nonviolence, he was on the front lines in the 1960s movement for racial justice.
item.dc:creator: Robert D. McFadden
item.media:credit: Lee Lockwood/The LIFE Images Collection via Getty Images
item.media:description: Mr. Vivian had a confrontation with an officer during a Freedom Ride from Montgomery, Ala., to Jackson, Miss., in 1961. After arriving in Jackson, Mr. Vivian was sent to prison, where he was beaten by guards.

item.title: Despite White House Broadsides, Most Americans Stick by Fauci
item.description: As President Trump and his allies have sown doubts about Dr. Anthony Fauci, many Republicans have turned against him. But over all, nearly two-thirds of the country expressed faith in Dr. Fauci.
item.dc:creator: Giovanni Russonello
item.media:credit: Doug Mills/The New York Times
item.media:description: Strikingly, one recent poll found that Dr. Anthony S. Fauci had the trust of a majority even in some of President Trump’s core demographics: white Americans without college degrees, people in rural areas and white men.
